text.p: - Slovenian Foreign Minister Davorin Kracun attended a meeting of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg on Thursday.
- The hearing at a Nicosia court on whether the assets of the former Yugoslavia in the offshore Beogradska Banka will remain frozen continues on Friday.
- Slovenian election campaign will end at midnight on Friday, a day before the country's second general election on Sunday.
- Finance Minister Mitja Gaspari said public spending increased this year mainly due to the rise in salaries in the public sector.
- Ski firm Elan expects to sell 40 percent of its ski production in the United States this year.
- The price of shares of Port Luka Koper is rising on the unlisted market ahead of an expected listing on the Ljubljana bourse at the end of November.
- Employers said on Thursday that the general collective agreement determining salaries and work benefits should be changed from next April.
- President Milan Kucan on Thursday presented research awards to five Slovenian experts, mainly in connection with scientific and engineering projects.
- Ljubljana city council is expected to decide whether the city's heating system should continue to use Slovenian coal, considered ecologically unsuitable for the capital.
- The government office of macroeconomic analysis said Slovenian GDP growth could be below three percent in 1996.
- Slovenian state prosecutor Anton Drobnic said on Thursday he was not aware that a computer diskette containing details of up to 150 prominent Slovenians had got into unauthorised hands.
- Slovenian state institutions said they would not be badly hurt by the possible bankruptcy of Komercialna Banka Triglav.
- From January, individuals will have to pay tax on profits made in the securities market.
